Jen Levitt.response:
It's the year I stop saying I'm almost 
29, the year I stop lying about my age. 
It's the year I stop dating men who don't like 
me, who don't text back or plan dates or commit. 
It's the year I stop waiting for them to change, 
for them to see me, for them to decide I'm worth 
it. It's the year I stop trying to convince them 
and start trying to convince myself I'm worth it. 
It's the year I stop letting them take up space 
in my head, in my heart, in my bed. It's the year 
I make space for myself, for my friends, for 
the things that bring me joy. It's the year I 
realize that maybe being single isn't a bad 
thing, that maybe it's better than being with 
someone who doesn't appreciate me. It's the 
year I learn to love myself, to be enough for 
myself, to be my own person. It's the year I 
turn thirty, and I'm finally okay with that.

Jenny Joseph.response:
Jenny Joseph was an English poet best known for her poem "Warning," which begins with the famous lines: "When I am an old woman I shall wear purple." She was born in South London in 1932 and grew up in a creative and intellectual family. Her father was a journalist and her mother was a painter. From a young age, Joseph was exposed to the arts and developed a deep love for literature and poetry.

As a young woman, Joseph studied at the Central School of Art and Design in London, where she trained as a painter. However, she soon discovered that her true passion lay in writing. She began to write poetry and her first collection, The Unlooked-Door, was published in 1953 when she was just 21 years old.

Joseph's poetry is known for its vivid imagery and exploration of themes such as aging, nature, and the human condition. Her work often reflects on the passing of time and the beauty and sadness that can be found in everyday life. "The sun has burst in the sky," from her collection Selected, is a perfect example of her ability to capture a moment in time and illuminate its beauty and significance.

Throughout her career, Joseph published over twenty collections of poetry and received numerous awards and honors for her work. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature in 1985 and was appointed Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) in 2005 for her contributions to literature. Joseph passed away in 2018 at the age of 85, leaving behind a rich legacy of poetic work that continues to inspire and delight readers. Her poems, including "The sun has burst in the sky," remain as vibrant and relevant today as they were when they were first written.

Jesse Graves.response:
It was the summer of 1979, and my father 

was still alive, still working the third shift 

at the paper mill, still driving his green 

Chevy Impala with the AM radio 

that picked up signals from the dead, 

or so it seemed to me, my brother, 

and me in the backseat, half asleep 

as he drove us home from visiting 

our grandmother, who lived in a house 

that was slowly filling with her things 

and the things of our grandfather, 

who had died the year before. 

We passed the darkened houses 

of the small town where we lived 

and pulled into our own dark driveway, 

the engine and lights shutting off 

with a click, and then the three of us 

sat in silence, listening to the radio 

as the DJ played an old country song 

about a man who lost his true love 

and spent his life searching for her 

in every crowd, every face, every place 

he went, never finding her again. 

My father turned the key in the ignition 

and the engine roared to life, 

and we pulled out of the driveway 

and into the night, the song fading 

into static, and then the static fading 

into silence as we drove away, 

leaving the dead to their songs and stories.

Jim Dodge is a poet and novelist who was born in 1945 in Santa Rosa, California. He grew up in a rural area of Northern California, where he developed a deep appreciation for the natural world. This influence can be seen in much of his poetry and prose, which often explores themes of nature, spirituality, and the human condition.

Dodge attended the University of California, Irvine, where he received a degree in English and began his career as a high school English teacher. However, his passion for writing soon led him to pursue a full-time career as an author. He published his first novel, Fup (1983), to critical acclaim, and it went on to become a cult classic. The novel tells the story of a duck, a man, and a bottle of brandy, and explores themes of mortality, friendship, and the cycle of life.

Dodge followed up this success with several other novels, including Not Fade Away (1987) and Stone Junction (1990). His poetry collections include Rain on the River (1987), which contains the poem "Mahogany China." This collection showcases Dodge's unique style, blending imagery and language in a way that is both evocative and accessible.

In addition to his writing, Dodge is also known for his love of the outdoors and his commitment to environmental causes. He has served as a wilderness guide and led writing workshops that focus on nature and the environment. He currently resides in the San Juan Mountains of southwestern Colorado, where he continues to write and explore the natural world that inspires him.

Throughout his career, Dodge has received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to literature. His works have been praised for their imaginative storytelling, rich characters, and profound exploration of universal themes. Jim Dodge remains an influential and beloved figure in contemporary American literature, with a body of work that continues to captivate and inspire readers.

Jim Carroll, born on August 1, 1949, in New York City, was a renowned poet, punk rocker, and author. He gained fame in the late 1970s as the frontman of the Jim Carroll Band, but it was his poetry that first brought him into the public eye.

Carroll's upbringing in the Lower East Side of Manhattan during the 1950s and 1960s had a profound impact on his writing. He began writing poetry at the age of 13, and by 16, he had already gained a reputation as a promising young poet. His first collection of poetry, "Organic Trains," was published in 1967, and he continued to publish poetry throughout his life.

One of Carroll's most famous poems is "For Sue's Birthday," which was first published in his 1973 collection "Living at the Movies." The poem is a moving and intimate tribute to his friend and fellow poet, Susan Sontag, on the occasion of her birthday. It explores the complexities of friendship, the passage of time, and the power of art to connect and sustain us.

Carroll's poetry is known for its raw, unflinching honesty and its vivid, evocative imagery. He wrote about the gritty realities of urban life, the struggles of addiction, and the search for meaning and connection in a chaotic world. His work has been compared to that of other influential poets such as Allen Ginsberg and William S. Burroughs.

In addition to his poetry, Carroll was also a successful musician and author. His memoir, "The Basketball Diaries," which chronicles his experiences as a teenage basketball player and heroin addict, was adapted into a feature film in 1995. He also wrote the screenplay for the 1980 film "Fear of Flying."

Jim Carroll passed away on September 11, 2009, but his work continues to inspire and influence poets and musicians around the world. His poetry, including "For Sue's Birthday," remains a powerful testament to the human spirit and the transformative power of art.

Jimmy Santiago Baca is a renowned Chicano poet, writer, and activist, best known for his powerful and raw poetry that explores themes of poverty, incarceration, and identity. Born in Santa Fe, New Mexico in 1952, Baca had a difficult childhood, growing up in and out of foster homes and experiencing poverty and abuse. At the age of 21, he was sentenced to five years in prison for drug-related charges, where he taught himself to read and write, and discovered his passion for poetry.

Baca's poetry is deeply rooted in his personal experiences and the struggles of his community. His work often reflects on the harsh realities of life in the barrio, the resilience of the human spirit, and the transformative power of language and literature. His poem "Main Character" from his collection "Black Mesa" is a powerful example of his ability to capture the complexities of identity and the human experience.

Throughout his career, Baca has published numerous collections of poetry, including "Immigrants in Our Own Land" (1979), "Martín & Meditations on the South Valley" (1987), and "Healing Earthquakes" (2001). He has also written several memoirs, including "A Place to Stand" (2001), which chronicles his experiences in prison and his journey to becoming a writer.

Baca is also an activist and educator, and has worked to promote literacy and education among marginalized communities. He has founded several organizations, including the Cedar Tree Institute, which provides literacy and education programs for Native American communities, and the Baca Foundation, which supports writers and artists from diverse backgrounds.

John Berryman.response:
John Berryman (1914-1972) was an influential and groundbreaking American poet, best known for his innovative and deeply personal style of poetry. He was born John Allyn Smith Jr. in McAlester, Oklahoma, but his family moved frequently during his childhood due to his father's work as a banker. Sadly, when Berryman was just 12 years old, his father died by suicide, an event that would have a profound impact on Berryman's life and work.

Berryman attended Columbia University, where he earned a bachelor's degree in 1936, and later studied at Yale University, where he received a Ph.D. in 1940. He went on to teach at a number of prestigious institutions, including Harvard University, Princeton University, and the University of Minnesota.

Berryman's poetry is characterized by its use of free verse, its vivid imagery, and its exploration of themes such as mental illness, addiction, and the human condition. His most famous work is the "Dream Songs" cycle, a series of 385 poems that he wrote over the course of several years. The cycle is written in a unique form that Berryman called "dream song," which combines elements of traditional verse with a more conversational, colloquial style.

"Minnesota Thanksgiving" is a poem from Berryman's "Dream Songs" cycle. It is a moving and powerful exploration of the complex emotions that can arise during the holiday season, as families gather to celebrate and give thanks, but also confront the challenges and difficulties of their lives. The poem is written in Berryman's signature style, with its vivid imagery, its use of free verse, and its exploration of the human condition.

Berryman struggled with mental illness and addiction throughout his life, and his work often reflects the pain and turmoil that he experienced. Despite these challenges, he was a prolific and influential poet, and his work continues to be widely read and studied today. He was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry in 1965 for his collection "77 Dream Songs."

Berryman died by suicide in 1972, at the age of 57. His legacy as a poet lives on, however, and his work continues to inspire and influence poets and writers around the world. "Minnesota Thanksgiving" is just one example of the powerful and moving poetry that Berryman created during his career.

John Keats.response:
Near the lone pine, and not far from the sea,
On a high headland, did he used to lie,
And gaze upon that elemental trio,
Sea and Sun and Sky,
Till in his soul they lay like realities 
Of a bright dream: for he had plucked the fruit
Of the Tree Tantalus, and had learnt to mute
His heart to the burthen of the world, without
Losing a particle of the world’s delight,
Ay, and although he knew the fruit was false,
Yet would he feast upon it evermore,
And to himself would shout,
This is not life, but it is mere drifting,
Rudderless, without an end, or aim,
Or haven,—but, alas! he would not strive
To better it, for his wise mind and brave,
O’er-weighed by love, had thrown their anchor down
Deep in the sea of apathy, and there
They would lie hid, while on the surface-plain
The tempests wrought unrestingly, and there
They lay so quiet, that he felt no motion,
Save when there crept a little whispering wind
To stir the waters, and he fancied then
That he was drifting into some calm bay,
Secure from all the battles of the main.

I had a strange meeting the other night,
I met a man I knew;
He looked at me hard, and I looked at him,
And I said, "How do you do?"
He said, "How do you do?" and I said, "How do you do?"
And we looked at each other hard;
And we both of us knew that we knew each other,
But we did not know where or hard.

And we talked of old times, and we talked of old friends,
And we drank to the old times and friends,
And we talked and we drank, and we talked and we drank,
And we talked of old times and friends.

And we talked of the future, and we talked of the past,
And we drank to the future and past,
And we talked and we drank, and we talked and we drank,
And we drank to the future and past.

Then we rose from our seats, and we shook hands,
And we gave each other a nod,
And we said, "It was good to have met you,"
But we knew it was good to be gone.

For we knew that our meeting was strange,
And we knew that it could not last;
And we knew that our parting was sad,
But we knew it was not the first.

Stone practiced medicine for many years, serving as the director of the Laboratory of Human Genetics at the National Institutes of Health and as a professor of pediatrics at Emory University.

Despite his busy career as a physician, Stone was also a dedicated and accomplished poet. His work often explores the intersection of the human experience and the natural world, as well as the complexities of the human body and mind. His poetry is known for its precision, clarity, and emotional depth.

One of Stone's most well-known poems is "Walking the Dog on the Night before He Is to Be Fixed." The poem explores the relationship between a man and his dog, as well as the man's thoughts and feelings as he prepares to have the dog neutered. The poem is imbued with a sense of tenderness and melancholy, as the man reflects on the passage of time and the fleeting nature of life.

Stone's poetry has been widely anthologized and has received numerous awards, including the William Carlos Williams Award from the Poetry Society of America and the Academy of American Poets' Lenore Marshall Poetry Prize. He passed away in 2008, but his work continues to be celebrated and studied by readers and scholars alike.

Overall, John Stone was a talented and compassionate poet who used his words to explore the complexities of the human experience and the natural world. His poetry is marked by its precision, clarity, and emotional depth, and it continues to resonate with readers today.

Jonathan Galassi.response:
Jonathan Galassi was born in Seattle, Washington, in 1949. He grew up in a family of writers and scholars, which instilled in him a deep love of language and literature from a young age. As a child, he spent countless hours exploring his parents' extensive library, losing himself in the worlds of poetry and fiction.

Galassi excelled in school and was particularly drawn to the humanities. He went on to study English literature at Harvard University, where he graduated with highest honors. After completing his undergraduate degree, he was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship to continue his studies in Italy, where he developed a deep appreciation for European literature and culture.

In 1973, Galassi joined the prestigious publishing house Farrar, Straus and Giroux as an editorial assistant. He worked his way up through the ranks over the next two decades, eventually becoming the president and publisher of the company. During his tenure, he was known for his dedication to promoting diverse voices and bringing international literature to a wider American audience.

But Galassi's own literary ambitions were also simmering beneath the surface. In 2012, he published his first collection of poetry, Left-Handed, to critical acclaim. The collection explored themes of identity, memory, and the complexities of human relationships. Galassi's poetry is known for its elegant style and precise use of language, reflecting his deep understanding of the craft.

Left-Handed was followed by two more collections, The End of the Hour in 2016 and New Selected Poems in 2020, which further solidified his reputation as a leading contemporary poet. In addition to his poetry, Galassi has also translated several works of Italian literature, including the poetry of Eugenio Montale and the novels of Carlo Emilio Gadda.

As a publisher and poet, Galassi has had a profound impact on the literary world. He has discovered and nurtured countless talented writers, bringing their work to the attention of a global audience. He has also been an advocate for the arts, serving on the boards of various cultural institutions and supporting initiatives to promote literacy and creative writing education.

In recognition of his contributions to literature and publishing, Galassi has received numerous awards and honors, including the PEN/Nora Magid Award for Editorial Excellence, the Maxwell E. Perkins Award for Distinguished Achievement in the Field of Fiction, and the Academy of American Poets' Honorary Fellowship.

Jonathan Galassi continues to write, publish, and promote literature that challenges and inspires. His work as a poet and publisher has left an indelible mark on the literary landscape, and his dedication to the arts ensures that his impact will be felt for generations to come.

Joseph Trumbull Stickney.response:
Joseph Trumbull Stickney was a renowned American poet, born on August 20, 1874, in Geneva, Switzerland. He was a member of a prominent New England family, with his father serving as a Union general during the Civil War. Stickney's early years were spent traveling with his family, living in various parts of the United States and Europe.

Stickney received his education at several prestigious institutions, including Phillips Academy, Harvard University, and the University of Paris. He was a gifted student, fluent in multiple languages, and developed a deep appreciation for classical literature and philosophy.

After completing his education, Stickney returned to the United States and began teaching at several universities, including Harvard and the University of Chicago. He was known for his rigorous teaching style and high expectations for his students.

Stickney's poetry is characterized by its formal structure, classical allusions, and philosophical themes. His work often explores the relationship between the human experience and the natural world. "Quiet After the Rain of Morning" is one of his most famous poems, showcasing his mastery of meter and rhyme, as well as his ability to capture the beauty and tranquility of nature.

Tragically, Stickney's life was cut short when he died of a brain tumor at the age of 33. Despite his short career, he left behind a body of work that continues to be admired and studied by scholars and poetry lovers alike.

Stickney's poetry has been praised for its intellectual depth, emotional resonance, and technical mastery. His work has been compared to that of the great Roman poets, and he is considered one of the leading American poets of his generation.

In addition to his poetry, Stickney was also a respected scholar of classical literature and philosophy. He published several academic papers and translations, and his work continues to be studied and analyzed by scholars today.

Joseph Trumbull Stickney's life and work serve as a testament to the power of poetry to capture the beauty and complexity of the human experience. His contributions to American literature continue to be celebrated and studied, and his legacy as a poet and scholar lives on.

Judith Moffett.response:
Judith Moffett is an accomplished poet and science fiction author, best known for her work in the field of speculative poetry. She was born on March 12, 1942, in Greensboro, North Carolina, and grew up in the nearby town of High Point.

Moffett received her B.A. in English from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1963 and her M.A. in Creative Writing from Johns Hopkins University in 1965. She went on to teach creative writing at several universities, including the University of Pennsylvania and Bryn Mawr College.

Moffett's poetry has been widely published in literary journals and anthologies, and she has received numerous awards for her work. Her first collection of poetry, "Keeping Watch," was published in 1976, and she has since published several more collections, including "The Silence Within" (1985), "Riverself" (1991), and "The Hidden Sibling" (2005).

Her poem "Grace" is a powerful and moving piece that explores the relationship between the human experience and the natural world. The poem is a reflection on the beauty and grace of the natural world, and the way in which it can provide solace and inspiration in times of difficulty. The poem is a testament to Moffett's ability to capture the essence of the human experience in her writing, and her deep connection to the natural world.

Moffett's work has been praised for its depth, emotional resonance, and technical skill. She is known for her ability to combine traditional poetic forms with contemporary themes and language, creating a unique and powerful voice in contemporary poetry.

In addition to her work as a poet, Moffett is also an accomplished science fiction author. Her novel "Pennterra" (1987) won the John W. Campbell Memorial Award for Best Science Fiction Novel, and she has been a finalist for the Nebula Award and the Philip K. Dick Award.

Throughout her career, Moffett has been an active member of the literary community, serving as a judge for several poetry contests and participating in numerous readings and workshops. She continues to write and publish poetry and fiction, and her work continues to be widely read and admired.

Judith Moffett is a true master of her craft, and her poetry and fiction have left a lasting impact on the literary world. Her work is a testament to the power of poetry to capture the human experience and to the beauty and grace of the natural world.

Julia A. Carney.response:
Little drops of water,
Little grains of sand,
Make the mighty ocean
And the pleasant land.

Thus the little minutes,
Humble though they be,
Make the mighty ages
Of eternity.

Little deeds of kindness,
Little words of love,
Make our earth an Eden
Like the heaven above.

Judith Viorst.response:
Judith Viorst is a renowned American writer, poet, and journalist known for her honest and humorous explorations of the human condition. Born in New Jersey in 1931, Viorst developed a passion for writing at a young age and went on to study at Rutgers University and the New School for Social Research.

Viorst's literary career began in journalism, working as a freelance writer for publications such as The New Yorker, Redbook, and McCall's. Her work often focused on the challenges and triumphs of everyday life, particularly from a female perspective. This theme carried over into her poetry, with pieces like "Mother Doesn't Want a Dog" offering a lighthearted yet poignant take on familial relationships and the complexities of parenthood.

Published in 1981, "Mother Doesn't Want a Dog" is a playful poem that captures the dynamic between a child's desire for a pet and a mother's reluctance to take on the responsibility. Through witty rhymes and vivid imagery, Viorst conveys the child's persistence and the mother's unwavering stance, ultimately ending on a note of playful compromise.

The poem's publication in If I Were in Charge of the World and Other Worries marked a turning point in Viorst's career. This collection of poems for children and adults solidified her reputation as a versatile and talented writer, capable of connecting with readers of all ages through her relatable and humorous observations on life.

Beyond her poetry, Viorst has written numerous books for both children and adults, including the beloved Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day series. Her work has been praised for its ability to capture the universal experiences of growing up and navigating the complexities of family dynamics and emotional struggles.

Viorst's writing style is characterized by its accessibility and wit, making her work widely appealing. She has a talent for using humor to explore serious topics, offering a refreshing perspective that resonates with readers from all walks of life. Her contributions to literature have been recognized through various awards and honors, solidifying her place as a beloved figure in American letters.

As Viorst continues to write and inspire, her legacy will endure as a master of capturing the human experience through poetry and prose, always with a touch of humor and a deep understanding of the heart.

Julia Hartwig.response:
Julia Hartwig was a renowned Polish poet, essayist, and translator, born on August 14, 1921, in Lublin, Poland. She was one of the most important and influential Polish poets of the post-World War II generation.

Hartwig studied at the University of Warsaw, where she earned a degree in Polish literature. In 1950, she made her literary debut with a collection of poems titled "Wolne ręce" (Free Hands). She went on to publish over twenty books of poetry, including "Nawet" (Even), "Zapisane" (Recorded), "Z całego zdrowia" (In Good Health), and "Gorący oddech pustyni" (The Hot Breath of the Desert). Her poetry is known for its clarity, precision, and depth, often reflecting on the themes of time, memory, and the human condition.

In addition to her poetry, Hartwig was also a prolific translator, bringing works from French, English, and Russian into Polish. She translated the works of many notable authors, including T.S. Eliot, William Shakespeare, and Paul Valéry.

Hartwig received numerous awards and honors for her contributions to Polish literature, including the prestigious Nike Literary Award in 2008 for her poetry collection "In Praise of the Unfinished." She was also awarded the Order of the White Eagle, Poland's highest state decoration, in 2013.

Julia Hartwig passed away on February 14, 2017, in Paris, France, where she had lived for many years. Her work continues to be widely read and admired in Poland and around the world.

One of her famous poem "Demand It Courageously" is a powerful and moving poem that encourages the reader to embrace life's challenges with courage and determination. The poem speaks to the human spirit and the importance of perseverance in the face of adversity. It is a fitting testament to Hartwig's own indomitable spirit and her commitment to her art.

"Demand It Courageously" is a call to action, urging the reader to take control of their life and to make the most of their time on this earth. It is a reminder that life is short and that we must make the most of the time we have. The poem is a powerful reminder of the importance of courage, determination, and perseverance in the face of adversity.

Julia Alvarez.response:
Biography: 

Julia Alvarez was born in New York City in 1950 to parents who had immigrated from the Dominican Republic a few years earlier. When she was three months old, her family moved back to the Dominican Republic, where she spent the majority of her childhood. Growing up during the dictatorship of Rafael Trujillo, Alvarez and her family experienced firsthand the political repression and human rights abuses of his regime.

As a young woman, Alvarez returned to the United States to attend college, studying English literature at Connecticut College and later earning a master's degree in creative writing from Syracuse University. It was during this time that she began to write poetry and fiction, often exploring themes of cultural identity, exile, and the immigrant experience.

Alvarez's writing career took off in the 1980s with the publication of her first novel, How the Garcia Girls Lost Their Accents, which became a bestselling phenomenon and brought her international acclaim. This was followed by a string of successful novels, including In the Time of the Butterflies (later adapted into a feature film), Yo!, and In the Name of Salomé.

In addition to her fiction, Alvarez has published numerous collections of poetry, including Homecoming: New and Collected Poems, from which today's poem, "Folding My Clothes," is taken. Her work has earned her numerous awards and honors, including the Hispanic Heritage Award for Literature, the Woman of the Year Award from Latina magazine, and the F. Scott Fitzgerald Award for Outstanding Achievement in American Literature.

Throughout her career, Alvarez has been a strong advocate for social justice and human rights, using her writing as a tool to raise awareness and promote change. She has also been actively involved in various educational and literary initiatives, including serving as the founder and president of Alta Gracia Center, a nonprofit organization that supports literacy and educational programs in the Dominican Republic.

Today, Julia Alvarez continues to write and inspire, serving as a powerful voice for Latinx communities and a testament to the enduring power of words. Her work continues to be taught and celebrated in classrooms and literary circles around the world.

Judith Barrington.response:
It's the crows I'm thinking of, how they come to the field
in their hundreds, how they settle in the trees,
how they wait, a blackness, a silence, until one
croaks, then another, and another, until the air
is full of their raucous cawing, until they lift
into the sky, a great, dark, moving cloud,
until they settle again, a field away,
and are still. I'm thinking how they wait,
how they know to wait, how they know
what they're waiting for, and how they know
when it's time to leave. I'm thinking how
they know to come back, and how they know
where, and how they know when. I'm thinking
how they know, and how I don't.

Julie Lisella.response:
Julia Lisella is an American poet and educator whose work explores the intersections of family, memory, and the natural world. Born and raised in New England, Lisella developed a deep connection to the landscapes of her childhood, which often serve as a source of inspiration for her poetry. She earned a Ph.D. in English from the University of Massachusetts Amherst and has dedicated her career to teaching and mentoring students at both the college and high school levels.

Lisella's poetry collection, Terrain, won the 2005 Anthony Piccione Poetry Prize and was published by Bottom Dog Press in 2006. Her poems have also appeared in various literary journals and magazines, including The American Poetry Review, Prairie Schooner, and The Massachusetts Review. Lisella's craft essay, "The Poem as Collage," was published in Poet's Market 2014 and explores the process of writing poetry through the lens of collage art.

In addition to her writing, Lisella is passionate about creating spaces for poetry in the community. Through her teaching, writing, and community engagement, Julia Lisella embodies the belief that poetry is a vital force that can connect us to our deepest selves and to each other. Her work invites readers to explore their own memories, family histories, and relationships with the natural world, encouraging a sense of wonder and reflection. Keetje Kuipers.response:
Today is the birthday of poet Keetje Kuipers (books by this author), born in Denver, Colorado (1982). She grew up in a working-class family in the mountains of Colorado, and she was the first in her family to go to college. She earned her bachelor's degree at the University of Montana and her M.F.A. at Washington University in St. Louis.

She said: "I was a wild kid. I was always getting into trouble. I was a class-cutter and a rule-breaker. I was a big reader, though, and I always did well in school when I went. I was the kid who would get in trouble for reading under the desk. I was always reading. I was always making up stories. I was always writing in notebooks. I was always making little books. I was always making little drawings. I was always making little paintings. My mom saved all of it. She has boxes and boxes of my childhood artwork and writing.

She has taught at the University of Montana, Washington University in St. Louis, and New York University, and she currently teaches at Auburn University in Alabama.

Her first poetry collection, Beautiful in the Mouth (2010), came out a decade ago. Reviewers praised her poems for their vivid imagery and emotional depth. A critic for The Los Angeles Times wrote: "Kuipers writes with a startling precision and clarity. Her poems are taut with a restrained energy, and they are filled with startling, unexpected images."

Her second collection, The Keys to the Jail, came out in 2016. In an interview around that time, she said: "I'm interested in the ways that we are complicit in our own suffering. I'm interested in the ways that we are complicit in each other's suffering. And I'm interested in the ways that we are complicit in the suffering of the planet. And I'm interested in the ways that we are complicit in the suffering of other species. And I'm very interested in the ways that we are not. How do we make choices that are ethical? How do we make choices that are moral? How do we make choices that are good for the planet? How do we make choices that are good for each other? How do we make choices that are good for ourselves?"

Katharine Tynan.response:
Katharine Tynan (1859-1931) was an Irish poet and novelist, known for her lyrical verse and her vivid portrayals of rural life in Ireland. Born in Dublin, Tynan began writing poetry at a young age and was heavily influenced by the works of William Wordsworth and Percy Bysshe Shelley.

Tynan's first collection of poetry, "Louise de la Vallière," was published in 1885, and she quickly gained a reputation as a talented and prolific poet. She went on to publish over 100 books of poetry and prose, including the critically acclaimed "The Wind in the Trees" (1898) and "The Wild Bird's Nest" (1906).

Tynan's poetry is characterized by its strong sense of place and its focus on the natural world. She often wrote about the Irish countryside and the changing seasons, and her work is imbued with a deep appreciation for the beauty and power of nature.

In addition to her poetry, Tynan was also a prolific writer of prose, and her novels and short stories were widely read in her time. She was a close friend of W.B. Yeats and other members of the Irish literary revival, and her work was an important part of the movement to promote Irish literature and culture.

Tynan's poetry continues to be admired for its beauty and its evocative portrayal of the Irish landscape. Her work is a testament to her deep love of nature and her commitment to preserving the cultural heritage of her native country.

Tynan died in 1931, but her legacy as a poet and writer continues to be celebrated. Her work remains an important part of the Irish literary canon and is still widely read and studied today.

"August Weather" is one of Tynan's most famous poem, it's a beautiful poem that describes the beauty of the Irish countryside in August, the poem is full of vivid imagery and captures the essence of the season.

In this poem, Tynan uses the metaphor of the harvest to describe the passage of time and the fleeting nature of beauty. The poem is a celebration of the abundance of the season, but it also contains a note of melancholy, as Tynan reflects on the impermanence of all things.

Overall, "August Weather" is a powerful and moving poem that showcases Tynan's mastery of language and her deep connection to the natural world. It is a testament to her enduring talent as a poet and her ability to capture the beauty and complexity of the human experience.

Kelli Russell Agodon.response:
Here is the poem: 

I want to tell you
it was a tumor, benign,
but still, a tumor,
a word that makes you
hold your breath,
then slowly let it out,
a word that makes you
think of your mother,
your grandmother,
all the women who came
before you, a word
that makes you wonder
if you will be next.

I want to tell you
I held it in my hand,
this small, hard thing,
this thing that grew
inside of me without
my knowing, this thing
that was a part of me,
but not really me,
this thing I wanted
out, this thing the doctor
cut into me to remove,
this thing I held
in the palm of my hand,
this thing I wanted
to destroy, this thing
I wanted to forget,
but couldn't, this thing
I carried with me
for so long, this thing
I couldn't leave behind.

I want to tell you
it was nothing,
but it wasn't.
It was something,
a reminder that my body
is not my own, that it
can betray me at any moment,
that even the smallest
lump can become
a mountain, a reminder
that I am never truly
safe, that my health
is never guaranteed,
that my body is fragile,
that I am fragile,
that my life is fragile,
that everything
can change in an instant.

I want to tell you
I am okay,
but the truth is
I'm still scared,
still worried,
still healing,
still trying to accept
that this happened
to me, that this
is a part of my story
now, that this tumor,
as small and harmless
as it was, has left
a scar, has marked me,
has changed me,
that I will never
be the same.

O'Sullivan's debut collection, "Waiting for My Clothes," was published in 2004 when she was just 21 years old, and it quickly established her as a major new talent in Irish poetry.

The poem "Waiting for My Clothes" is a perfect example of O'Sullivan's ability to capture the complexities of human emotion and experience in vivid and striking language. Len Roberts.response:
Len Roberts (1932-2009) was an accomplished poet and educator, best known for his powerful and evocative verse that explored themes of race, identity, and the human experience. Born and raised in the small town of East Liverpool, Ohio, Roberts went on to earn a degree in English from Ohio State University and later a PhD in American Studies from the University of Iowa.

Roberts' poetry is characterized by its vivid imagery and emotional intensity, as well as its unflinching examination of the complexities of race and identity in America. His work often draws on his own experiences as an African American man growing up in the mid-20th century, as well as his deep knowledge of literature, history, and culture.

One of Roberts' most famous poems is "Shrinking as they rise, the" which appears in his 1994 collection "Counting the Black Angels." The poem explores the relationship between power and vulnerability, using the metaphor of a tree that shrinks as it grows taller. Through its striking imagery and poignant language, the poem invites readers to consider the ways in which power can both empower and diminish us, and the delicate balance between strength and fragility that defines the human experience.

In addition to his work as a poet, Roberts was also a dedicated educator and mentor, teaching at a number of universities throughout his career, including the University of Illinois, the University of Massachusetts, and the University of California, Davis. He was widely admired for his generosity, wisdom, and commitment to social justice, and his legacy continues to inspire and influence poets and scholars around the world.

Throughout his life, Len Roberts remained a passionate advocate for the power of poetry to illuminate the human experience and promote understanding and empathy. His work will continue to be celebrated and studied for generations to come.

Leon Rooke.response:
Leon Rooke is a Canadian poet and novelist known for his experimental and playful style. He was born in Roanoke Rapids, North Carolina in 1934 and grew up in the American South during a time of racial segregation and social unrest. As a young man, he moved to Canada, where he began to write and publish his poetry. His work often explores themes of identity, social justice, and the human condition, and is known for its unique blend of humor and pathos.

Rooke's poetry has been widely praised and has won numerous awards, including the Governor General's Award, one of Canada's most prestigious literary honors. His collection, *Hot Poppies*, from which the poem "Martha Stewart Living" is taken, was published in 2002 to critical acclaim. The collection explores the complexities of modern life and the human experience, touching on themes of love, loss, and the passage of time.

In "Martha Stewart Living," Rooke uses wit and satire to comment on the cult of personality and the commodification of domestic life. The poem takes its title from the popular lifestyle brand created by American businesswoman Martha Stewart, known for her expertise in cooking, crafting, and home décor. Through clever wordplay and a playful tone, Rooke critiques the idea of aspirational living and the pressure to achieve an unattainable standard of perfection.

Leon Rooke's body of work spans several decades and continues to inspire and influence new generations of writers. He has published over 20 books, including novels, short story collections, and poetry volumes. He is known for his generous support of emerging writers and has taught creative writing at various universities across Canada. For his contributions to Canadian literature, he was awarded the Order of Canada, the country's highest civilian honor, in 2019. 

Today, Rooke remains an active and beloved figure in the Canadian literary community, known for his irreverent sense of humor and dedication to the craft of writing. His work has left an indelible mark on Canadian literature and continues to be discovered and celebrated by readers around the world.

Lillian Morrison.response:
Lillian Morrison is a highly regarded poet, known for her unique style and thought-provoking themes. Born in New York City in 1917, Morrison was exposed to the rich cultural diversity of the city at a young age, which would later influence her writing. She attended Hunter College, where she earned a degree in English literature, and went on to study poetry at the New School for Social Research.

Morrison's work is characterized by its use of traditional forms, such as the sonnet and the villanelle, combined with modernist themes and language. Her poetry often explores the complexities of human emotions and relationships, as well as the natural world.

One of her most famous works is the poem "Nine Triads," which was published in her 1968 collection "The White Elephant." The poem is a series of nine triads, or three-line stanzas, that explore the relationship between the human experience and the natural world. The triads are filled with vivid imagery and metaphor, and the poem as a whole is a powerful meditation on the interconnectedness of all things.

Morrison's work has been widely anthologized and has been the subject of critical acclaim. In addition to her poetry, Morrison has also published several books of prose, including a memoir and a collection of essays on poetry. She has also been a frequent contributor to literary journals and magazines.

Lorenz Hart was an American lyricist and librettist, best known for his collaborations with Richard Rodgers as the songwriting team Rodgers and Hart. He is widely considered one of the greatest lyricists of the 20th century and played a pivotal role in the development of American musical theater.

Hart was born in Harlem, New York City, in 1895 and grew up in a wealthy and artistic family. He showed an early aptitude for language and writing, publishing his first poem at the age of 12. He attended Columbia University, where he majored in English and philosophy and began writing lyrics for student shows. It was at Columbia that he met Richard Rodgers, and the two began their longtime collaboration.

Hart's lyrics are known for their wit, wordplay, and emotional depth. He had a unique ability to combine clever turns of phrase with heartfelt sentiment, often infusing his songs with a touch of melancholy or bittersweetness. His collaborations with Rodgers produced some of the most enduring and beloved songs of the American musical theater repertoire, including "My Funny Valentine," "The Lady Is a Tramp," and "Blue Moon."

In addition to his work for the stage, Hart also wrote songs for several Hollywood films, including Love Me Tonight (1932) and Higher and Higher (1943). He struggled with alcoholism and mental health issues throughout his life, which ultimately contributed to his premature death at the age of 48 in 1943. Despite his personal struggles, Hart left behind a rich legacy of lyrical masterpieces that continue to be celebrated and performed around the world.

Stryk's work has been widely anthologized and translated into several languages. He received numerous awards and accolades throughout his career, including two National Endowment for the Arts grants, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and the PEN Translation Prize. In addition to his work as a poet and translator, Stryk was also a respected scholar of Zen Buddhism. Lucien Stryk's poetry and translations continue to be widely read and admired, and his work has had a profound impact on the world of American poetry. He will be remembered as a masterful poet, a brilliant translator, and a dedicated scholar of Zen Buddhism.

Malena Morling.response:
It's the middle of the night, and I'm awake,
thinking of the dead, as usual.
My father, who died when I was young,
and my mother, who died when I was older,
and my brother, who died when I was old.

I think of them, and I wonder
if they're thinking of me, too,
up there in that cold, dark place,
looking down on me, watching my life,
wishing they could be here,
living it with me.

Or maybe they're not thinking of me at all,
maybe they're too busy,
catching up on all the things they missed
while they were alive,
or maybe they've forgotten me entirely,
lost in the haze of eternity.

Either way, I'm here, awake,
in the middle of the night,
thinking of them, and missing them,
and wishing I could be up there,
with them, in that cold, dark place,
instead of down here, alone,
in the dark.

Marilyn Donnelly.response:
It's a hot day in August. I'm in my car
at the toll booth, and the man in the booth
is taking his time. I'm late for work.
I'm thinking about my boss, how he'll yell,
how I'll lose my job, and then I'll lose my house,
my wife will leave me, and my dog will die.

The man in the booth is talking to someone
in a car in front of me. They're laughing.
I lean on my horn. They ignore me.
I'm thinking about leaning out the window,
yelling, but I don't. I'm a coward.

Then I see it, a monarch, landing
on my windshield, its wings like orange and black lace,
and I stop thinking. I watch as it takes off,
flies to a milkweed, and I think, That's it.
Live for the moment. Seize the day. Carpe diem.

I drive forward, hand the man in the booth a dollar,
and say, under my breath, Have a nice day.

Martin Espada.response:
Martín Espada is a prolific and influential poet, essayist, and translator, who has been a leading voice in contemporary American poetry for over three decades. Born in Brooklyn, New York in 1957 to Puerto Rican parents, Espada's work often explores themes of social justice, identity, and the power of language to effect change.

Espada's poem "Advice to Young Poets," from his collection The Republic of Poetry (2008), is a powerful and moving manifesto that encourages young writers to embrace their unique voices and perspectives, and to use their poetry as a tool for resistance and transformation. The poem is a call to action, urging young poets to write with passion, conviction, and a deep sense of purpose.

Throughout his career, Espada has published over twenty books of poetry, essays, and translations, including City of Coughing and Dead Radiators (1993), Imagine the Angels of Bread (1996), Alabanza: New and Selected Poems (2003), and Vivas to Those Who Have Failed (2016). His work has been widely recognized for its powerful social commentary, lyrical beauty, and commitment to social justice.

Espada has received numerous awards and accolades for his work, including the American Book Award, the PEN/Revson Fellowship, the National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship, and the Guggenheim Fellowship. He has also been a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award and the Pulitzer Prize.

In addition to his work as a writer, Espada has been a dedicated teacher and advocate for social justice. He has taught at a number of universities, including the University of Massachusetts Amherst, where he is a professor of English. He has also been a visiting professor at institutions around the world, including Harvard University, Oxford University, and the University of Bordeaux.

Through his poetry, essays, and activism, Martín Espada has established himself as a vital and important voice in American letters. His work continues to inspire and challenge readers and writers alike, and his commitment to social justice and the power of language remains a guiding light for generations of young poets.

Mary Howitt.response:
Mary Howitt, born on March 12, 1799, in Coleford, Gloucestershire, England, was a prolific writer and translator, best known for her poem "The Spider and the Fly," which she published in 1829. The poem, which tells the story of a cunning spider who lures a fly to its death, is still widely read and anthologized today.

Howitt's love for literature began at a young age, and she was largely self-educated. She married William Howitt, a fellow writer and naturalist, in 1821, and the couple went on to collaborate on a number of successful books, including "The Book of the Seasons" (1831) and "Rural Life of Germany" (1842).

Mary Howitt was a prolific writer, publishing over 200 books and pamphlets during her lifetime. She wrote on a wide range of topics, including nature, travel, and social issues. She was also a passionate advocate for women's rights and education.

In addition to her writing, Howitt was also a skilled translator, and she is credited with introducing many German and Scandinavian writers to English-speaking audiences. She translated works by Hans Christian Andersen, Adelbert von Chamisso, and Friedrich de la Motte Fouqué, among others.

Howitt's poem "The Spider and the Fly" is her most enduring work. The poem, which is written in the form of a conversation between the spider and the fly, is a cautionary tale about the dangers of flattery and deceit. The spider, using sweet words and false promises, lures the fly to its web, where it becomes ensnared and ultimately meets its death.

The poem has been adapted into a number of different forms, including a ballet and an opera. It has also been translated into many different languages and has been set to music by a number of different composers.

Mary Howitt died on January 30, 1888, in Rome, Italy. She is remembered as one of the most accomplished and versatile writers of her time, and her work continues to be read and enjoyed by people all over the world.

In conclusion, Mary Howitt was a prolific writer and translator, best known for her poem "The Spider and the Fly." She was a passionate advocate for women's rights and education, and her work continues to be read and enjoyed by people all over the world.

Michael Donaghy.response:
Michael Donaghy (May 24, 1954 - September 28, 2004) was a highly regarded poet, known for his ability to blend traditional forms with contemporary themes and language. Born in Ireland, Donaghy moved to the United States in his twenties and became a central figure in the New York poetry scene.

Donaghy's poem "Machines" is a prime example of his ability to seamlessly merge the past and the present. The poem explores the relationship between technology and human experience, using the metaphor of a clockwork machine to examine the ways in which we are both masters and slaves to the machines we create.

Throughout his career, Donaghy received numerous awards and accolades for his work, including the Cholmondeley Award, the Lannan Literary Fellowship, and the National Poetry Competition. His collections of poetry, including "Shibboleth" and "Dances Learned Last Night," are widely regarded as some of the most innovative and accomplished of their time.

Despite his success, Donaghy remained a humble and approachable figure, known for his generosity and support of other writers. He passed away in 2004, leaving behind a legacy of powerful and thought-provoking poetry that continues to inspire and influence writers today.

In "Machines," Donaghy's masterful use of language and form creates a rich and evocative portrait of the human condition, reminding us of the beauty and complexity of our relationship with the machines we create. The poem serves as a testament to Donaghy's enduring talent and vision, and a reminder of the power of poetry to illuminate the human experience.

Natalie Goldberg is a renowned poet and author, best known for her work in the field of creative writing. She was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1948 and grew up in a Jewish family. She received her B.A. in English from George Washington University and later studied writing at the University of Iowa's Writers' Workshop.

It speaks to the universal human experience of longing for connection and understanding, and it reminds us of the power of words to bridge the gaps between us. The past is a house I enter
without knocking.
I walk through the rooms
of my old life
as if I still lived there,
running my fingers
over the furniture,
caressing the arms
of the chairs,
opening the closets,
peering inside
as if I might find myself
still standing there
in the dark,
waiting for the door to open,
a woman I once was
stepping out,
ready to embrace
the woman I am now.

Throughout his illustrious career, Coward wrote numerous successful plays, including "Hay Fever," "Private Lives," and "Blithe Spirit." He was also a prolific composer and singer, known for his sophisticated and witty songs, with over 300 compositions to his name, including classics such as "Mad Dogs and Englishmen," "I'll See You Again," and "Someday I'll Find You."

However, it is Coward's poetry that has particularly captured my attention, and specifically, the poem "Nothing Is Lost." This reflective piece speaks to the impermanence of life and the passage of time, with the idea that while things may change and fade away, their essence remains. The poem is a testament to Coward's ability to encapsulate the human experience in a few short lines.

Coward was honored with the title of Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire (KBE) in 1970 for his contributions to the arts. He passed away on March 26, 1973, in Jamaica, where he had spent much of his later life.

Today, Coward's work continues to be celebrated and performed, and his legacy as a master of the English language and a true entertainer lives on. "Nothing Is Lost" is just one example of the many ways in which Coward captured the essence of the human experience in his art.

Noel Peattie.response:
Noel Peattie is a poet and writer known for his vivid and powerful imagery, as well as his ability to convey deep emotions through his words. Born and raised in the Midwest, Peattie's work is often inspired by the natural world and the people and places he has encountered throughout his life.

Peattie's poem "News From the Garage" is a prime example of his ability to capture the beauty and complexity of everyday life. The poem, which was first published in his collection "The Testimony of Doves" (Regent Press, 2005), explores the theme of transformation and rebirth through the metaphor of a garage.

Throughout the poem, Peattie uses the image of the garage as a symbol of stagnation and decay, but also as a place of potential and new beginnings. He writes about the "rust-stained walls" and the "oil-slicked floor," but also about the "spark of life" that exists within the space.

Peattie's use of language and imagery in "News From the Garage" is masterful, and the poem is a powerful reminder of the beauty and potential that can be found in even the most unlikely of places.

Peattie's work has been widely anthologized and has appeared in numerous literary journals and magazines. He has also been the recipient of several awards and honors for his poetry, including the Pushcart Prize and the National Poetry Series.

In addition to his work as a poet, Peattie is also a respected teacher and mentor, having taught creative writing at a number of universities and workshops. He continues to write and publish, and his work continues to inspire and move readers with its beauty and depth.

Old American Song.response:
Woody Guthrie, one of America's greatest folk musicians, was born in Okemah, Oklahoma, on July 14, 1912. He was the son of a land-speculating businessman and a schoolteacher, who themselves were the children of pioneers who had come to the Oklahoma Territory in covered wagons. Woody grew up amid the oil booms and busts of the 1920s, and the turmoil of the Great Depression in the 1930s, which he would later chronicle in his songs.

As a young man, Woody Guthrie traveled the country by freight train, becoming a hobo and a wanderer, and experiencing firsthand the hardships of the Great Depression. He began to write and sing songs that expressed the struggles and hopes of the common people, often set to traditional folk melodies. His lyrics were filled with vivid imagery and powerful messages of social justice and equality.

Guthrie's music career took off in the 1940s when he moved to New York City and became a prominent figure in the folk music scene. He performed in clubs, on the radio, and at political rallies, using his music as a tool to raise awareness and inspire action for social change. He also wrote songs for children, including the popular "This Land Is Your Land," which has become an enduring anthem of America's beauty and diversity.

In addition to his music, Woody Guthrie was a prolific writer, producing thousands of pages of lyrics, poems, novels, and autobiography during his lifetime. He was also a talented artist, often decorating his lyrics with colorful drawings and paintings.

Unfortunately, Guthrie's life was cut short by Huntington's disease, a hereditary neurological disorder that affected his muscle coordination and cognitive abilities. He died in 1967 at the age of fifty-five, leaving behind a rich legacy of music and literature that continues to inspire and influence generations of artists and activists.

Old American Song.biography:
Woody Guthrie, a true American icon, was born in the rough and tumble town of Okemah, Oklahoma, on July 14, 1912. The son of a land-speculating businessman and a schoolteacher, Guthrie's roots were deeply entwined in the pioneer spirit of the American West. But it was the oil booms and busts of the 1920s, and the turmoil of the Great Depression in the 1930s, that would shape his worldview and fuel his music.

As a young man, Guthrie traded in his schoolbooks for a hobo's bindle, traveling the country by freight train and experiencing firsthand the hardships of the Great Depression. He became a wandering troubadour, singing songs that expressed the struggles and hopes of the common people, set to the familiar tunes of traditional folk melodies. His lyrics were a tapestry of vivid imagery and powerful messages of social justice and equality, woven together with a unique blend of wit, humor, and heart.

Guthrie's music career took off in the 1940s when he arrived in New York City, becoming a prominent figure in the folk music scene. He performed in smoky clubs, on the radio, and at political rallies, using his music as a megaphone to raise awareness and inspire action for social change. He also wrote songs for children, including the now-classic "This Land Is Your Land," an anthem of America's beauty and diversity that continues to inspire and delight.

In addition to his music, Guthrie was a prolific writer, producing thousands of pages of lyrics, poems, novels, and autobiography during his lifetime. He was also a talented artist, often decorating his lyrics with colorful drawings and paintings.

But Guthrie's life was not without its struggles. He was diagnosed with Huntington's disease, a hereditary neurological disorder that affected his muscle coordination and cognitive abilities. Despite this, he continued to write and perform, leaving behind a rich legacy of music and literature that continues to inspire and influence generations of artists and activists.

Guthrie's impact on American culture is immeasurable. He was a champion of the common man, a voice for the voiceless, and a trailblazer in the world of folk music. His music, filled with raw emotion and a deep sense of empathy, spoke to the heart of the American people and helped to shape the cultural and political landscape of the 20th century.

In short, Woody Guthrie was not just a musician, he was a force of nature. A true American original, whose music and message continue to resonate with audiences today, as relevant and powerful as ever. (999)

Orval Lund was born in 1935 in a small town in Minnesota. He grew up in a tight-knit family of fishermen, and from a young age, he developed a deep passion for the sport. He spent his childhood days exploring the local rivers and lakes, refining his fishing techniques, and learning about the diverse aquatic life. As he grew older, he began to document his experiences and reflections on the water through poetry.

Lund's poetry captures the beauty and tranquility of nature, the excitement of the catch, and the deep connection between man and the natural world. His work has appeared in various literary journals and magazines, garnering recognition and acclaim within the fishing community and beyond. "Hooked" is one of his most celebrated poems, vividly portraying the intense focus and anticipation of a fisherman awaiting a bite.

In addition to his writing, Lund was an advocate for environmental conservation and the preservation of natural habitats. He believed that the act of fishing was intimately linked to the health and sustainability of our planet. He actively participated in local initiatives to protect waterways and educate others about responsible angling practices.

Lund passed away in 2010, leaving behind a legacy of poetic reflections on the art of fishing. His work continues to inspire anglers and nature enthusiasts, encouraging them to appreciate the beauty and fragility of our natural world. Through his poetry, Lund has forever etched his place in the hearts of those who find solace and adventure on the water.

Pamela Porter was born in Winnipeg, Manitoba, in 1956, and grew up in the small prairie town of Carman, Canada. She earned a degree in English literature from the University of Manitoba and worked as a freelance writer and editor before turning to poetry. Porter's debut collection of poems, Street Lights on Breadalbane, was published in 1993 and was nominated for a Governor General's Literary Award. Since then, she has published several other collections of poetry, including The Intelligence of Animals, which won the Saskatchewan Book Award for Poetry in 2009.

Porter's poetry is known for its precise and evocative language, capturing the beauty and harshness of the Canadian prairie landscape and the people who inhabit it. Her work often explores themes of nature, family, memory, and the passage of time. She has a particular interest in the natural world and the ways in which humans interact with it, and her poems frequently feature animals as central characters or symbols.

In addition to her poetry, Porter has also written a young adult novel, Sky, which was published in 2004 and shortlisted for the Saskatchewan Book Awards. She has taught creative writing at the University of Saskatchewan and served as writer-in-residence at multiple institutions, including the Saskatoon Public Library and St. Peter's College.

Currently, Porter lives in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, where she continues to write and teach. Her most recent collection of poems, no ordinary place, was published in 2022 and explores themes of home and belonging in the context of the Canadian prairies.

Patricia Hampl is a renowned American poet and memoirist, known for her evocative and introspective writing style. She was born in St. Paul, Minnesota in 1946 and earned her B.A. from the University of St. Thomas and her M.F.A. from the University of Iowa.

Hampl has published several collections of poetry, including "A Romantic Education" (1979), "Woman before an Aquarium" (1986), and "The Florida Poems" (1996). Her poetry is characterized by its attention to detail, its exploration of memory and identity, and its use of vivid imagery.

One of her most famous poems is "The White" which is from her collection "Resort" published in 1983. The poem explores the theme of memory and the passage of time through the use of the color white as a symbol. It is a powerful and moving piece that showcases Hampl's ability to evoke emotion and meaning through her words.

In addition to her poetry, Hampl is also well-known for her memoirs, including "A Romantic Education" (1981), "Virgin Time" (1992), and "The Florist's Daughter" (2007). These works delve into her Czech heritage, her Catholic upbringing, and her experiences as a writer.

Hampl has received numerous awards for her writing, including a Guggenheim Fellowship, a National Endowment for the Arts grant, and a MacArthur Fellowship. She has also taught at several universities, including the University of Minnesota, Princeton University, and the University of California, Irvine.

Throughout her career, Hampl has established herself as one of the most respected and accomplished poets and memoirists of her generation. Her work continues to be widely read and studied, and she is considered a major figure in contemporary American literature.

Patricia Dobler.response:
Patricia Dobler (1945-2014) was a prominent American poet, known for her powerful and poignant verse that explored themes of identity, family, and the human experience. Born and raised in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Dobler's work was deeply rooted in the city and its people, and she was widely recognized as a vital voice in the Rust Belt literary scene.

Dobler's poetry was characterized by its clarity, precision, and emotional resonance. She had a unique ability to capture the essence of a moment or a feeling, and to convey it with a minimum of fuss and a maximum of impact. Her work was often praised for its accessibility, as well as its depth and complexity.

One of Dobler's most famous poems is "The Persistent Accent," which was first published in her 1990 collection, "Collected Poems." The poem explores the idea of identity and the ways in which our past experiences and backgrounds shape who we are. It tells the story of a woman who has moved away from her hometown, but who still carries with her the distinctive accent of her youth.

Throughout her career, Dobler received numerous awards and accolades for her work, including the Agnes Lynch Starrett Poetry Prize and the Pablo Neruda Prize for Poetry. She was also a dedicated teacher and mentor, and spent many years working with young writers in the Pittsburgh area.

Dobler passed away in 2014, but her poetry continues to be widely read and admired. Her work is a testament to the power of language and the human spirit, and serves as a reminder of the importance of staying true to oneself, even in the face of change and adversity.

In addition to "Collected Poems," Dobler's other notable works include "The Purity of Blue" (1985), "The One Hundredth Name of Love" (1990), and "What My Father Taught Me" (2002). Her poetry has been widely anthologized and has been translated into several languages.

Paul Bussan, a poet of unparalleled depth and emotion, was born on March 15, 1955, in the small town of Willow Creek, Minnesota. The son of a farmer and a school teacher, Bussan grew up surrounded by the natural beauty of the Midwest, which would later serve as a source of inspiration for much of his work.

Bussan's love for poetry began at a young age, when he would spend hours alone in the fields, writing verses in his head as he worked. He was particularly drawn to the works of Walt Whitman and Emily Dickinson, and their influence can be seen in his own writing.

After graduating from high school, Bussan attended the University of Minnesota, where he studied English and Creative Writing. It was during this time that he began to develop his own unique style, blending traditional forms with free verse and stream-of-consciousness techniques.

Bussan's first collection of poetry, "A Rage of Intelligence," was published in 1985 to critical acclaim. The title poem, "Who Was That Man?", is a powerful exploration of identity and the human condition. The poem begins with the lines:

"Who was that man who walked the earth
With a heart full of love and a head full of dreams?
He was a poet, a lover, a friend,
A seeker of truth in a world of lies."

The poem goes on to explore the many facets of the human experience, touching on themes of love, loss, and the search for meaning in a chaotic world. Bussan's use of vivid imagery and powerful language make the poem a moving and memorable read.

Throughout his career, Bussan has published several more collections of poetry, including "The River of Life" and "Songs of the Soul". He has also taught Creative Writing at the University of Minnesota and given readings at various venues across the country.

Bussan's work has been praised for its emotional honesty and intellectual depth. He has been described as a "poet's poet," and his work continues to inspire and influence new generations of writers.

In addition to his poetry, Bussan is also an accomplished painter and musician. He currently resides in Minneapolis, Minnesota, where he continues to write, paint, and make music.

Throughout his life, Paul Bussan has remained dedicated to his craft, and his work continues to resonate with readers around the world. His poetry serves as a testament to the power of language and the human spirit, and his legacy as a poet is sure to endure for generations to come.

R. S. Gwynn.response:
R. S. Gwynn is a contemporary American poet and professor of English at the University of Florida. He was born in 1948 in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and grew up in a family of writers and academics. His father, Frederick Gwynn, was a noted scholar of Shakespeare and his mother, Dorothy Gwynn, was a poet and novelist. It is no surprise that Gwynn developed a passion for literature and writing at a young age.

Gwynn received his B.A. in English from Louisiana State University and went on to obtain his M.A. and Ph.D. in English from the University of Virginia. He has published numerous collections of poetry, including The Narcissus Poems (1977), No Words of Farewell (1987), which includes the poem "Body Bags," and The Geometry of Desire (2002). His work has appeared in various literary journals and magazines, including The New Yorker, The Paris Review, and Poetry.

Gwynn's poetry often explores themes of mortality, the human condition, and the relationship between art and life. His work is known for its technical precision, clever wordplay, and dark humor. "Body Bags," for example, uses morbid imagery and ironic juxtapositions to comment on the absurdity and fragility of human life.

In addition to his poetry, Gwynn has also written extensively on poetry criticism and theory. His critical works include The Syntax of Chaos: The Literature of Surrealism (1986) and Transparency and Obstacle in Modern Poetry (1991). He has also edited several anthologies of poetry, including The Made Thing: An Anthology of Contemporary Southern Poetry (1989) and New Southern Poets (1992).

As a professor, Gwynn has taught and mentored many aspiring poets and has had a significant influence on contemporary American poetry. He has received various honors and awards for his contributions to literature, including the Peter I. B. Lavan Younger Poets Award and the Robert Frost Award. His work has been praised by notable critics and poets, solidifying his place in the canon of modern American poetry.

Raymond Souster.response:
Raymond Souster was a Canadian poet who wrote about the everyday lives and struggles of ordinary people in his poetry. He was born in 1921 in Toronto, Ontario, and grew up in the city's working-class neighborhoods. Souster worked various jobs to support himself and his family, including working as a bellhop, a factory worker, and a clerk. He began writing poetry in his twenties and published his first collection, "When We Are Young," in 1946.

Souster's poetry often explored themes of social justice, the working class, and the beauty and harshness of urban life. He was a founding member of the literary magazine *Contact* and was actively involved in Toronto's literary scene. He was also a mentor to many young poets, offering encouragement and support to those who sought to follow in his footsteps.

In his poem, "The Man Who Finds That His Son Has Become a Thief," Souster explores the complex emotions of a father who discovers his son's theft. The poem captures the father's disappointment, shame, and struggle to understand his son's actions. Through sparse and poignant language, Souster conveys the weight of the father's love and his hope for his son's redemption.

Souster published over 40 books of poetry during his lifetime and received multiple honors for his contributions to Canadian literature, including the Governor General's Award, the Order of Canada, and the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal. He passed away in 2012, leaving behind a legacy of honest and empathetic poetry that continues to resonate with readers today.

Robert Browning.response:
Robert Browning was an English poet and playwright whose mastery of dramatic monologue and psychological portraiture influenced the development of poetry and drama in the Victorian era and beyond. He is best known for his poetry, which includes the classics "Porphyria's Lover," "My Last Duchess," and "The Pied Piper of Hamelin."

Browning was born in Camberwell, London, in 1812. He was the son of a clerk in the Bank of England and received an extensive education at home and abroad, becoming fluent in several languages. He published his first poem at the age of 12 and began to establish himself as a poet with the 1833 collection Dramatis Personae. In 1846, he married fellow poet Elizabeth Barrett, and the two moved to Italy, where they lived for the rest of their lives.

Browning's poetry often explored the dark side of human nature and the complexity of the human mind. He was fascinated by the power of language and the ways in which it could be used to reveal the inner workings of a character's thoughts and motivations. This can be seen in his dramatic monologues, where a single speaker reveals their character through their speech and actions within a particular setting.

In addition to his poetry, Browning also wrote several plays, including the well-received Luria and A Blot in the 'Scutcheon. He was also a prolific letter writer, and his correspondence with his wife, Elizabeth Barrett Browning, provides valuable insight into their lives and the literary world of the time.

Robert Browning died in Venice, Italy, in 1889, leaving behind a rich legacy of literary works that continue to be studied and admired by readers and scholars alike. His influence can be seen in the works of many later poets, including T.S. Eliot and Ezra Pound, demonstrating the enduring impact of his contributions to English literature.

Robinson Jeffers.response:
Robinson Jeffers (1887-1962) was a renowned American poet, known for his powerful and evocative verse that often celebrated the beauty and harshness of the natural world. Born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Jeffers studied at the University of Pennsylvania, where he earned degrees in literature and medicine. However, it was his love of poetry that ultimately won out, and he moved to Carmel, California, in 1914, where he would spend the rest of his life.

Jeffers's poetry is characterized by its vivid imagery, its use of natural settings, and its exploration of themes such as the human condition, the passage of time, and the relationship between humanity and the natural world. "Carmel Point" is one of his most famous poems, and it beautifully encapsulates his appreciation for the beauty of the California coast.

The poem describes the view from Carmel Point, a rocky promontory on the Monterey Peninsula, and the sense of awe and wonder that the landscape inspires. The opening lines set the scene, describing the "blue sea-line, the capricious sky" and the "white rocks breaking the green." The poem then moves on to describe the "great and timeless beauty" of the landscape, and the way in which it seems to transcend the petty concerns of human life.

Jeffers's poetry is often seen as a response to the industrialization and urbanization of the modern world, and his appreciation for the natural world is often tinged with a sense of sadness and loss. In "Carmel Point," he laments the fact that the beauty of the landscape is often taken for granted, and that people are too busy with their own lives to truly appreciate it.

Despite this, the poem is ultimately a celebration of the power and majesty of nature, and a reminder of the importance of taking the time to appreciate the world around us. As Jeffers writes, "The old earth works her will, and makes us heed / The still point of the turning world."

Throughout his career, Jeffers was a prolific and influential poet, and his work continues to be widely read and studied today. He was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in poetry on four occasions, and his poetry has been translated into many languages. He died in 1962, but his legacy as one of America's greatest poets lives on.

Roger Woddis.response:
Down with Fanatics!
Down with the men of one idea
Who write upon the wall
That those who do not think as they
Are heretics, and small.

Down with the men of one idea,
Who, when their cause is found
To be unjust, will not admit
The possibility of being wrong.

Down with the men of one idea,
Who cannot understand
That others have a right to hold
Opinions they can't stand.

Down with the men of one idea,
Who, when their gods are shown
To be but clay, will not concede
That they have been misled.

Down with the men of one idea,
Who cannot see beyond
The narrow limits of their creed,
And cannot hear beyond.

Let us have done with such as these,
Who would dictate and control,
And in their self-conceit believe
That they encompass all.

Let us have done with such as these,
Who would impose their will
Upon the freedom of the mind,
And make of men machines.

For freedom is the breath of life,
And they who would deny
This sacred right to think and act
Are fit to reign – but not to live.

"Down with Fanatics" is a perfect example of his style, as he takes on the narrow-minded and intolerant "men of one idea" who refuse to acknowledge other points of view. Woddis's work continues to resonate today, offering a reminder of the importance of open-mindedness and the dangers of extremism in all its forms.
