Ron Koertge.response:
This is the hour when the heat presses
down like a fat thumb. The lizards
have taken cover. The birds have shut up.
Even the bees have stopped their small motors.
The whole world is taking a nap,
and I am the only one awake,
sipping my drink with its little umbrella,
watching the bougainvillea blaze
against the white wall, and feeling
like the last person on Earth.

Born in 1939 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Brown demonstrated an early aptitude for language and writing. She received her B.A. from Cornell University and went on to earn an M.A. in English Literature from the University of Chicago.

Brown's literary career began in the 1960s with the publication of her first volume of poetry, The No-Travels, in 1965. This was followed by several other poetry collections, including Some Deaths, which won the Carl Sandburg Award, and The Country of Lost Parents. Her poetry often delves into personal and emotional subjects, such as love, loss, and the complexities of family relationships.

Her debut novel, Autobiography of My Mother, published in 1976, received critical acclaim and was a finalist for the National Book Award. This was followed by other notable novels, including Tender Mercies, Civil Wars, and Half a Heart. Brown's novels often feature strong female characters navigating complex emotional landscapes and struggling with issues of identity and personal history.

Brown's writing has earned her numerous awards and accolades, including the Carl Sandburg Award, the Janet Heidinger Kafka Prize, and fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation. She has taught creative writing at various universities, including Northwestern University and the University of Houston, and has been a visiting writer at many others.

In addition to her literary achievements, Brown has also been active in social and political causes. She has been a vocal advocate for women's rights and gender equality, and her work often reflects her commitment to social justice and exploring the complexities of the human experience.

As a poet and novelist, Rosellen Brown continues to inspire and captivate readers with her honest and insightful explorations of the human condition. Her body of work stands as a testament to her talent and her ability to give voice to the deepest emotions and experiences that unite and define us.

Samuel Johnson.response:
Samuel Johnson, also known as "Dr. Johnson," was a renowned poet, essayist, and lexicographer born in Lichfield, England in 1709. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest literary figures of the English language and his works continue to be studied and admired to this day.

One of Johnson's most well-known poems is "Winter: An Ode," which was published in 1728 when he was just 19 years old. The poem is a reflection on the beauty and harshness of the winter season, and it showcases Johnson's mastery of the English language and his ability to convey complex emotions through poetry.

Despite the early success of "Winter: An Ode," Johnson's life was marked by hardship and struggle. He was plagued by poor health and financial difficulties throughout his life, but he persevered and continued to write and publish. In 1747, he published his famous "A Dictionary of the English Language," which took him nine years to complete and established him as one of the leading literary figures of his time.

Johnson's later years were marked by his close friendship with the writer James Boswell, who wrote a famous biography of Johnson after his death in 1784. Johnson's legacy as a poet, essayist, and lexicographer continues to be celebrated and his works remain an important part of the English literary canon.

In "Winter: An Oode" Johnson wrote:

"No longer now the business of the day
Through the dark region of the frosty sky
Shall wake the peasant from his snowy bed,
And the loud curfew toll the twilight hours:
No more the roaring of the wintry sea
Shall be heard on the bare and distant shore,
Nor the shrill wind, through the leafless grove,
Murmur with hollow sound, and rustling leaves."

This stanza is a perfect example of Johnson's ability to capture the essence of winter and its impact on the natural world. His use of vivid imagery and descriptive language paints a picture of a cold, dark and quiet world, where the usual sounds of the day are replaced by the silence of the snow.

Johnson's poetry, like his life, is marked by a deep sense of introspection and a profound understanding of the human condition. His works continue to be read and studied, and his contributions to English literature are still celebrated today. Samuel Johnson died in 1784, but his legacy as a poet, essayist, and lexicographer lives on.

Sharlot Mabridth Hall.response:
Sharlot Mabridth Hall (October 27, 1870 – April 9, 1943) was an American poet, historian, and the first woman to hold an elected office in the Arizona Territory. She was also a musician and an artist. Hall is best known for her poetry, which often explored the history and culture of the American West. She was born in Lincoln County, New Mexico, and her family moved to Arizona when she was a child. Hall grew up in the small town of Prescott, which would become a frequent setting for her poems. She was educated by private tutors and showed an early aptitude for language and the arts. In addition to her poetry, Hall painted and played the piano and violin.

As a young woman, Hall began to involve herself in the political and social issues of her day. She was particularly concerned with the treatment of Native Americans and women's rights. In 1891, she published a collection of her poems, including "Boot Hill," which brought her widespread acclaim. The poem "Boot Hill" is a poignant reflection on the lives and deaths of cowboys in the Wild West, and it has become one of Hall's most famous works. Hall's poetry often combined a sense of rugged individualism with a deep appreciation for the beauty and harsh realities of life on the frontier.

In 1912, Hall was elected Territorial Historian of Arizona, becoming the first woman to hold an elected office in the territory. She used her position to advocate for the preservation of Arizona's history and culture, and she worked to establish a number of museums and historical societies. Hall remained active in politics and community affairs until her death in 1943. Today, she is remembered as a pioneering figure in Arizona history and a talented poet who captured the spirit of the American West in her work.

Born in 1886 into a wealthy family, Sassoon enjoyed a privileged upbringing and developed a passion for writing from a young age. He was educated at Cambridge University, where he studied law and economics, but his heart belonged to literature and poetry.

However, the horrors of war had a profound impact on him, and he became increasingly disillusioned and vocal in his opposition to the conflict. Sassoon's war poetry is characterized by its stark realism and emotional intensity, vividly depicting the brutality and senselessness of war. His most famous works include "The Old Huntsman," "Counter-Attack," and "Suicide in the Trenches," which portray the physical and psychological trauma endured by soldiers in the trenches.

In 1917, Sassoon's open letter entitled "Finished with the War: A Soldier's Declaration" brought him to the attention of the military authorities, and he was declared unfit for further service. After the war, Sassoon continued to write and publish poetry, as well as memoirs and novels. He traveled extensively, lectured on poetry, and was actively involved in veteran's affairs. He was also a mentor to several aspiring writers, including the famous poet and novelist, Wilfred Owen.

Towards the end of his life, Sassoon converted to Catholicism and found solace in his faith. He passed away in 1967, leaving behind a rich literary legacy that continues to inspire and influence readers and writers today. Sir Samuel Ferguson was a prominent Irish poet, barrister, and antiquarian of the nineteenth century. Born on March 10, 1810, in Belfast, Ireland, Ferguson was a key figure in the Irish literary renaissance of the Victorian era.

Susan Eisenberg is a renowned poet and labor activist, best known for her groundbreaking collection of poetry, "Pioneering: Poems From the Construction Site." The book, published by Cornell University Press, features the poem "Toward Ambidexterity," which showcases Eisenberg's unique ability to capture the experiences and struggles of women working in male-dominated industries.

Eisenberg's poetry is deeply rooted in her own experiences as one of the first women to work in the construction trades. She began her career as a wireman in the early 1970s, and her poetry reflects the challenges and triumphs she faced in this predominantly male world. "Toward Ambidexterity" is a powerful example of Eisenberg's ability to convey the physical and emotional demands of this work, as well as the resilience and determination of the women who do it.

Throughout her career, Eisenberg has been a tireless advocate for women in the trades and has worked to raise awareness about the issues they face. Eisenberg's poetry has been widely anthologized and has received numerous awards, including a PEN New England Discovery Award and a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts. She has also been a featured poet at the Library of Congress and has given readings and workshops at universities and conferences across the country.

In addition to her work as a poet and activist, Eisenberg is also a skilled craftswoman and artist. She has created sculptures and installations that explore the themes of work, gender, and power, and her work has been exhibited in galleries and museums throughout the United States.

Through her poetry and activism, Susan Eisenberg has made a significant contribution to the literature of work and gender and has inspired a new generation of women to pursue careers in the trades. Suzanne Matson.response:
Here lies the body of my wife:
I marvel at its stiffness.
She’s laid out in her best black dress,
A fine silk, and a bit too tight.

I always thought that she was cold,
But now I see it’s just her flesh
That has this chill about it, like
The marble of our fireplace,

Or ice, or steel, or frozen pond—
Unmoving, and untouchable.
They say that death is very hard
On those left living, but for me

It’s been a kind of softening,
A warming up, as if my heart
Had been until this moment wrapped
In layers of her icy flesh

And now at last I am released
To feel the sun, the summer breeze,
To let my blood flow as it will,
No longer chilled and stiff and still.

Born in Des Moines, Iowa, Disch was raised in a Catholic family and attended local schools before attending the University of Minnesota.

Disch's poetry was known for its wit, intelligence, and technical precision. He published his first collection of poetry, "High Musical," in 1968, and went on to publish several more collections, including "The Right Way to Figure Plumbing" (1972), "On Wings of Song" (1979), and "Burn This" (1982). His poetry often explored themes of technology, sexuality, and the human condition, and he was known for his use of traditional forms and meters, as well as his experimentation with free verse.

In addition to his poetry, Disch was also a prolific and influential science fiction author. He published his first novel, "The Genocides," in 1965, and went on to write many more, including "Camp Concentration" (1968), "334" (1972), and "The Brave Little Toaster" (1980). Disch was also a respected literary critic, writing for publications such as The New York Times, The Nation, and The New York Review of Books. He was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award in 1980 for his collection of essays "The Castle of Indolence: On Poetry, Poets, and Poetasters."

Disch's work was widely recognized during his lifetime, and he received numerous awards and accolades, including two Nebula Awards, a John W. Campbell Memorial Award, and a Rhysling Award. He passed away in 2008 at the age of 68.

Thomas Lynch.response:
It's a small thing, this poem, this life,
this matchbook God has struck for us to see
how darkness, with a little spark, becomes
a room, a street, a countryside, a sea,
how light, with just a little to go on,
becomes the whole of what we know,
how night, with just a little day upon it,
becomes a lake the moon can row across,
how we, with just a little luck, become
the thing we never thought we'd be,
how love, with just a little work, can be
the rest of the story, how the rest of the story
can be love, how the story can be
rest, how rest can be the story, how
the story can be how we rest, how we
can be the story, how the story ends
and how it goes on, how it goes on and on.

Moore attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he was an active participant in the Free Speech Movement. It was during this time that he began writing poetry, and his work quickly gained attention for its political and social commentary.

After graduating from Berkeley, Moore traveled extensively throughout the United States and Europe, immersing himself in the burgeoning Beat poetry scene. He became friends with many of the leading figures of the movement, including Allen Ginsberg, Jack Kerouac, and William S. Burroughs.

Moore's poetry is known for its raw, unfiltered style and its focus on social and political issues. He has been praised for his ability to capture the spirit of the Beat generation and for his contributions to the literary canon.

Tom Wayman.reflected_response:
Thomas "Tom" Wayman, a celebrated and impactful Canadian poet, was born on August 8, 1945, in Madison, Wisconsin, USA. Renowned for his poetry that delves into themes of labor, class, and the working experience, Wayman has published over twenty collections and has been extensively anthologized in both Canada and the United States.

Raised in Englewood, New Jersey, Wayman developed an early interest in literature and social justice. He pursued his passion for writing at the University of California, Berkeley, where he earned a Bachelor's degree in English. In 1967, Wayman moved to Canada, where he would become a prominent figure in the country's literary scene.

Wayman's work is deeply rooted in his experiences and observations of the working class. His poems offer powerful insights into the lives of laborers, often challenging societal norms and advocating for workers' rights. Among his most notable collections are "Waiting for Wayman" (1981), "Did I Miss Anything?" (1982), and "The Astonished Universe" (1984).

In addition to his contributions to poetry, Wayman has also been an influential educator. He has taught at various universities, including the University of Calgary, the University of Victoria, and the University of British Columbia. Wayman has inspired countless students and fellow writers with his dedication to the craft and his commitment to social change.

Throughout his career, Wayman has received numerous accolades for his work, including the Governor General's Award for Poetry nomination in 1980 for "The Book of Evenings" and the Canadian Authors Association Award for Poetry in 1987 for "The Face of Jack Munro."

Thomas Wayman remains a vital voice in Canadian poetry, continuing to inspire and challenge readers with his thought-provoking work. His poetry serves as a testament to his unwavering commitment to social justice and the working class.

Tony Hoagland.response:
Tony Hoagland was born in 1953 in Fort Bragg, North Carolina, and raised in a military family that moved frequently. He earned a BA from the University of Iowa, an MA from the University of Arizona, and an MFA from the University of Iowa. He taught for many years at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and has also taught at the Iowa Writers' Workshop, Warren Wilson College, and the University of Houston.

Hoagland is the author of six books of poetry, including Priest Turned Therapist Treats Fear of God (2018), Application for Release from the Dream (2015), and Unincorporated Persons in the Late Honda Dynasty (2010), which was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award. His honors include the Jackson Poetry Prize, the Mark Twain Award, and fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts.

Hoagland's poetry often engages with contemporary American culture and society, exploring themes of consumerism, materialism, and the human condition in the modern world. His work is known for its wit, irony, and sharp observations about everyday life. He has said that he aims to write poetry that is "accessible and useful to a wide range of readers," and his work has been praised for its ability to speak to a broad audience.

In an interview, Hoagland said, "I try to write poems that are funny, sad, and true all at the same time. I want them to be entertaining, but I also want them to have some emotional depth and to say something meaningful about the human experience." His poetry has been described as "provocative," "surprising," and "deftly crafted," and he has been hailed as "one of the most original and compelling voices in American poetry today."

Tony Hoagland passed away in 2018 at the age of 64, leaving behind a significant body of work that continues to resonate with readers and influence new generations of poets. His poetry remains a testament to his unique perspective on the human condition and his enduring contribution to the literary world.

Unknown.response:
I stand amid the roar
Of a surf-tormented shore,
And I hold my dead child in my arms.

Alone.

We have lingered long and late,
My child and I, by this bright sea;
Now she is dead, and I
Stand alone by the shore of a troubled sea.

She was fair as the sun, and she shone
Like a star in the summer night;
She was proud as a queen, yet she lay
In my arms last night, and her breath was sweet.

Now she is dead, and the moon shines bright,
And the wind blows cold on the sea;
And I stand alone by the shore of a troubled sea.

I shall never forget that night,
When the wind blew wild, and the waves beat high,
And the rain fell fast on the window-pane;
And I held her close, and she smiled at me.

Now she is gone, and the night is dark,
And the wind blows cold on my heart;
But I stand alone, and my soul is strong,
And I shall never forget that night.
Unknown.reflected_response:
Biography

"Unknown" is a poignant and powerful poem that explores the enduring grief and loneliness of a parent who has lost a child. The speaker in the poem stands on a shore, holding their dead child, reflecting on their time together and the beauty and pride the child brought to their life. The imagery of the turbulent sea and the cold wind captures the speaker's inner turmoil and the overwhelming sense of loss. The repetition of "alone" emphasizes the speaker's isolation and the finality of their child's death. The poem is a raw and emotional expression of grief, serving as a testament to the depth of a parent's love and the enduring pain of their loss.

Twyla Hansen.response:
Twyla M. Hansen is a renowned poet and author, known for her powerful and evocative verse that explores the complexities of the human experience. Born and raised in Nebraska, Hansen's writing is deeply rooted in the landscape and culture of the Great Plains.

Hansen's poem "Trying to Pray" is a prime example of her ability to capture the beauty and struggle of rural life. The poem follows the speaker as they try to connect with something greater than themselves, reaching out in prayer amidst the chaos and challenges of everyday life.

Throughout her career, Hansen has published several collections of poetry, including "Dirt Songs: A Plains Duet" (2011), "Potato Soup" (2003), and "Rock Tree Bird" (2017), from which "Trying to Pray" is taken. Her work has been widely anthologized and has earned her numerous awards, including the Willa Award for Poetry and the Nebraska Book Award.

Hansen is also a dedicated advocate for the arts and the environment. She has served as the Nebraska State Poet, a position appointed by the governor, from 2013 to 2018. In this role, she worked tirelessly to promote poetry and literacy throughout the state, visiting schools, libraries, and community organizations to share her love of language and the written word.

Hansen's poetry is a testament to the power of the human spirit and the beauty of the natural world. Her work invites readers to slow down, to observe, and to connect with the world around them, offering a sense of peace and solace in a chaotic world.

In "Trying to Pray," Hansen shows us that even in the midst of struggle and hardship, there is always the possibility of connection and grace. Her poetry is a gift to us all, reminding us of the beauty and power of language and the human spirit.

Veronica Patterson.response:
Veronica Patterson is a poet and educator whose work explores the intersections of art, history, and the natural world. Her debut collection, Swan, What Shores?, was published by New York University Press and received widespread critical acclaim. The collection showcases her signature style, blending lush imagery with precise observations to create poems that are both visually stunning and intellectually engaging.

Through her poetry, Patterson invites readers to examine the ways in which art, in its many forms, can offer new perspectives and insights on the world around us. Many of her poems are inspired by works of art or artists themselves, such as Edward Hopper and Claude Monet, reflecting her belief that poetry and art are inherently linked.

In addition to her creative work, Patterson is dedicated to fostering a love of poetry and art in others. She currently teaches creative writing and poetry workshops in schools and community centers, using art as a jumping-off point to spark creativity and self-expression in her students.

Growing up in a family of artists, Patterson was exposed to the world of art from a young age. She often visited museums and galleries with her parents and developed a deep appreciation for the power of art to inspire and transform. This early exposure to art informs her poetry and her teaching practice, as she strives to create work that is accessible and meaningful to a wide range of readers.

Before publishing Swan, What Shores?, Patterson's poems appeared in various literary journals and magazines, including The New Yorker, Poetry, and American Poetry Review. She has received several awards and honors for her work, including a Pushcart Prize and a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts.

In addition to her writing and teaching, Patterson is an active member of the literary community, participating in readings and festivals across the country. She currently resides in Brooklyn, New York, where she continues to write and teach, inspiring new generations of poets and art enthusiasts. 

With her unique perspective and captivating poetry, Veronica Patterson has established herself as a rising star in the world of poetry, leaving her mark on the page and in the hearts and minds of her readers.

Virginia Hamilton Adair.response:
Virginia Hamilton Adair was born on September 28, 1913, in Helena, Arkansas. She was an American poet, known for her vivid imagery and mastery of traditional poetic forms. She published her first poem at the age of eight in the children's section of the New York Times.

Adair earned a bachelor's degree from Mount Holyoke College in 1934 and a master's degree from Columbia University in 1935. She went on to teach at several colleges and universities, including Barnard College, the University of Michigan, and the University of California, Los Angeles.

Despite her early success as a poet, Adair's writing was put on hold for several decades as she focused on her teaching career and raising her family. It wasn't until she retired from teaching in 1979 that she returned to writing poetry.

In 1996, at the age of 82, Adair published her first full-length collection of poems, "Anthills of the Savannah," which was later re-titled "Ants on the Melon: A Collection of Poems." The collection includes the poem "Cutting the Cake," which explores the themes of time, memory, and the passing of life.

Adair's work has been praised for its wit, intelligence, and emotional depth. She has been compared to poets such as Elizabeth Bishop and Marianne Moore.

In addition to her poetry, Adair was also known for her love of gardening and her knowledge of horticulture. She passed away on August 16, 2004, at the age of 90.

Throughout her life, Virginia Hamilton Adair's poetry was praised for its vivid imagery, mastery of traditional forms, and exploration of themes such as time, memory, and the passing of life. Her work continues to be celebrated and studied by scholars and poetry lovers alike.

Virgil Suarez.response: Virgil Suárez was born in Havana, Cuba, in 1962, and came to the United States with his family when he was a child, just before the Cuban Missile Crisis. His family settled in Miami, Florida, where Suárez grew up and where he still lives and teaches. He is the author of several books of poetry and prose, including Guide to the Blue Tongue, From Ybor City, and Spared Angola. His work often explores the immigrant experience and the cultural hybridity of living between two worlds. He has received numerous awards for his writing, including a Florida Arts Council Individual Artist Fellowship and a Cintas Fellowship. His poems have appeared in various literary journals and magazines, and he has been invited to read and teach at universities across the United States and abroad. In addition to his writing, Suárez is also a dedicated teacher and mentor to emerging writers. He currently teaches in the MFA program at Florida International University.

W. C. Handy.response:
William Christopher Handy, also known as W.C. Handy, was a renowned musician, composer, and publisher, born on November 16, 1873, in Florence, Alabama. Handy is often referred to as the "Father of the Blues" and is best known for his composition "St. Louis Blues," which has become a jazz and blues standard.

Handy grew up in a musical family, with his father being a minister and his mother a singer. He learned to play several instruments, including the cornet, guitar, and piano, and began his career as a musician in his early twenties. He traveled throughout the South, playing in various bands and orchestras, and eventually settled in Memphis, Tennessee.

In Memphis, Handy formed his own band, the Memphis Blues Band, and began to experiment with the blues, a genre that was then still in its infancy. He was one of the first musicians to notate and publish blues compositions, and his work helped to popularize the genre and bring it to a wider audience.

"St. Louis Blues" was first published in 1914 and quickly became a hit. The song's haunting melody and poignant lyrics, which tell the story of a woman whose lover has left her for another, resonated with audiences and helped to establish Handy as a leading figure in the world of blues music.

Handy continued to compose and publish music throughout his life, and his work had a profound influence on the development of jazz and blues. He passed away on March 28, 1958, in New York City, but his music and legacy continue to live on.

Handy was inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame in 1980 and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1998. He was also awarded a posthumous Pulitzer Prize Special Citation in 2019 for his contributions to American music.

Handy's "St. Louis Blues" remains one of the most beloved and enduring songs in the American songbook, and it continues to be performed and recorded by musicians around the world. The song has been adapted as a jazz standard, and has been performed by artists such as Louis Armstrong, Ella Fitzgerald, and B.B. King.

Handy's life and work serve as a testament to the power of music to bring people together, to express emotion, and to tell stories that resonate with audiences across generations. He will always be remembered as a pioneering figure in the world of blues and jazz, and as a true American musical icon.

Wallace McRae.response:
Wallace McRae, the Cowboy Poet of Montana, was born in 1936 and raised on a ranch in the Jawbone country of southwestern Montana. He grew up riding, roping, and working cattle, and these experiences formed the foundation of his poetry. McRae's poetry is known for its vivid depictions of cowboy life, capturing the beauty and hardship of the western landscape and the rugged individuals who call it home. His work celebrates the traditions and values of the cowboy way of life, honoring the close connection between man and nature.

McRae's poetry has been widely celebrated, and he has been invited to perform at venues across the country, including the National Cowboy Poetry Gathering in Elko, Nevada. He has published several collections of his poems, including *Cow Tracks* (1985) and *Range Fired* (1994). In addition to his poetry, McRae is also known for his expertise in horse training and farriery, often combining his love of horses with his poetic talents.

McRae's influence extends beyond the world of poetry, as he is credited with helping to revive and popularize the art of cowboy poetry in the late 20th century. He inspired a new generation of cowboy poets and ensured that the traditions and stories of the American West would continue to be shared and celebrated. Today, his poems remain a testament to the enduring spirit of the West and a lasting legacy of a life dedicated to the cowboy way.

Wendy Cope is a highly regarded and much-loved English poet, known for her wit, humor, and keen insight into the human condition. Born in Erith, Kent, in 1945, Cope studied English at St Hilda's College, Oxford, before working as a teacher for many years.

Cope's poetry often explores themes of love, relationships, and the everyday, with a lightness of touch and a keen ear for the rhythms and cadences of speech. "From June to December: Summer Villanelle" is one of her most famous poems, and showcases her ability to capture the complexities of human emotion in a seemingly simple and straightforward way.

The poem explores the passing of time and the changing of the seasons, as well as the ups and downs of a romantic relationship. The villanelle form, with its repetition of certain lines, adds a sense of structure and order to the poem, even as it explores the unpredictable and sometimes chaotic nature of love.

Cope has published several collections of poetry, including "Making Cocoa for Kingsley Amis" (1986), "Serious Concerns" (1992), "If I Don't Know" (2001), and "Family Values" (2011). She has won numerous awards for her work, including the Cholmondeley Award, the Michael Braude Award for Light Verse, and the National Poetry Competition.

In addition to her poetry, Cope has also written several books for children, as well as a memoir, "Family Values" (2011), which explores her own family history and the influence it has had on her work.

Throughout her career, Wendy Cope has established herself as one of the most distinctive and engaging voices in contemporary English poetry. Her work is characterized by its wit, intelligence, and emotional depth, and has touched the hearts and minds of readers around the world.

Wesley McNair.response:
This Poem
by Wesley McNair
I wrote this poem
for the woman who asked me
to write a poem about her
and then broke my heart.
I wrote it for the man
who told me to get a real job
and then lost his own.
I wrote it for the boy
who threw a rock at a bird
and wept when it fell dead from the sky.
I wrote it for the girl
who dreamed of being a dancer
but ended up waiting tables.
I wrote it for the old man
who never got over his fear of dogs
and died of a heart attack
when one chased him.
I wrote it for the young woman
who gave up everything for love
and found herself alone.
I wrote it for the soldier
who survived two tours of duty
only to be killed by a drunk driver.
I wrote it for the single mother
working two jobs to feed her kids
and still struggling to make ends meet.
I wrote it for the addict
who knew he was killing himself
but couldn't stop.
I wrote this poem
for all the broken-hearted,
the lost, the lonely,
the ones who never gave up
even when the world
told them they should.
I wrote it for you.
I wrote it for me.
I wrote it for everyone
who needs to hear
that they are not alone,
that someone else understands,
that life is hard
but also beautiful,
that there is always hope,
even when it seems impossible.
I wrote this poem
because I had to,
because it was the only way
I knew how to make sense
of all the pain and joy
that comes with being alive.
Wesley McNair.reflected_response: Wesley McNair was born in 1941 in Pittsfield, Maine, and grew up in a working-class family. He received his B.A. from the University of Maine in 1963 and his M.A. from the University of Minnesota in 1968. He has published over a dozen books of poetry, including The Lost Child: Selected Poems (2009), The Ghosts of You and Me (2022), and The Unfastening (2017), which includes the poem "This Poem." McNair's poetry often explores themes of loss, memory, and the natural world, and he is known for his accessible and poignant verse. In addition to writing, McNair has taught creative writing at a number of institutions, including the University of Maine and the Bread Loaf Writers' Conference. He served as the Poet Laureate of Maine from 2011 to 2016 and was awarded the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize in 2014 for his outstanding contribution to American poetry. Wesley McNair's work continues to inspire and resonate with readers, offering a profound exploration of the human condition through his artful and insightful poetry.

William Allingham, who was born in 1824 in Ballyshannon, Ireland, was a poet and writer known for his lyrical poems and ballads that often drew inspiration from Irish folklore and mythology. He began writing at an early age and published his first poem when he was just sixteen years old. Allingham's work was well-received during his lifetime, and he became a key figure in the Victorian literary scene, contributing to prominent publications such as Fraser's Magazine and The Spectator.

One of Allingham's most famous works is the lyric poem "The Faeries," which explores the magical world of Irish folklore and captures the imagination of readers with its vivid descriptions and enchanting atmosphere. In addition to his poetry, Allingham also wrote prose, including a collection of Irish fairy tales and a biography of his close friend, the painter Dante Gabriel Rossetti.

Allingham's poetry is characterized by its musical quality, with a focus on rhythm and meter that creates a lyrical, song-like effect. His use of imagery and descriptive language brings his poems to life, whether he is depicting the natural beauty of Ireland or delving into the mythical and supernatural.

In his later years, Allingham suffered from poor health and was unable to continue his writing career. He passed away in 1889, leaving behind a legacy of enchanting poetry that continues to captivate readers and inspire new generations of Irish writers. His work has secured his place as one of the most important figures in Irish literary history.

Robert Browning was an English poet and playwright whose dramatic monologues and unique use of language have made him a enduring figure in the literary world. Born in 1812 in Camberwell, London, Browning began writing at a young age and published his first poem at nineteen. He was particularly influenced by the poetry of Percy Bysshe Shelley, and his early work shows a strong romantic sensibility.

Browning's poetry is known for its dramatic and theatrical quality, with many of his poems taking the form of monologues delivered by a single speaker. This style allows him to explore a wide range of themes and characters, from the passionate and rebellious to the dark and enigmatic. His use of language is often innovative and experimental, blending colloquialisms with more formal poetic diction.

One of Browning's most famous poems is "Porphyria's Lover," a chilling tale of obsession and murder told from the perspective of the murderer. Other notable works include "My Last Duchess," "The Pied Piper of Hamelin," and "Fra Lippo Lippi." He also wrote several plays, including the historical tragedy "Strafford" and the comedic "Colombe's Birthday."

In 1846, Browning married fellow poet Elizabeth Barrett, and the two moved to Italy, where they lived for much of their married life. Their love story inspired a number of films and novels, including the 2009 movie "The Barretts of Wimpole Street." Browning passed away in 1889, leaving behind a rich literary legacy that continues to be studied and celebrated worldwide.

Greenway has published several collections of poetry, including "Fishing at the End of the World," which includes the poem "Theater." The poem explores the relationship between the human experience and the natural world, using the metaphor of a theater to illustrate the ways in which we are both actors and observers in the grand drama of life.

Throughout his career, Greenway has received numerous awards and accolades for his work, including the Pushcart Prize and the James Dickey Prize for Poetry. His poetry has been widely anthologized and has appeared in numerous literary journals and magazines.

In addition to his work as a poet, Greenway is also a respected educator and scholar. He has taught at several universities, including the University of North Carolina at Greensboro and the University of West Georgia, where he is currently a professor of English. Greenway's poetry is known for its vivid imagery, emotional depth, and intellectual rigor. His work invites readers to consider the complexities of the human experience and the beauty and mystery of the natural world. Through his poetry, Greenway offers a unique and powerful perspective on the human condition, one that is both grounded in the everyday and reaching for the transcendent.

Despite his many accomplishments, Greenway remains a humble and dedicated artist, committed to his craft and to sharing his vision with others. He continues to write and publish poetry, and to teach and inspire new generations of writers and readers.

William Harmon.response:
William Harmon is a poet and educator whose work explores the intricacies of human experience and the complexities of memory. Born in 1938 in Richmond, Virginia, Harmon grew up in a family that valued literature and the arts. From an early age, he displayed a passion for poetry and language, often spending hours lost in the worlds created by words.

As a young man, Harmon attended the University of Virginia, where he studied English and fell under the mentorship of renowned poet and professor Charles Wright. Under Wright's guidance, Harmon honed his craft, developing a style that blended precise imagery with a deep exploration of emotional and psychological states.

After graduating with a Master of Fine Arts, Harmon began his career as a teacher, sharing his love of poetry and literature with students of all ages. He taught at various institutions, including the University of Virginia and Columbia University, before settling into a long-term position at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

It was during his time at UNC that Harmon's own poetic career began to flourish. He published his first collection of poems, "Notes for a New Age," in 1977, followed by several other volumes over the next two decades. His poetry has been widely praised for its lyrical beauty and profound insights into the human condition.

In addition to his work as a poet, Harmon is also known for his scholarship and criticism. He has edited numerous anthologies of poetry, including the influential "The Vintage Book of Contemporary American Poetry." He has also published critical studies of poets such as Robert Frost and Elizabeth Bishop, offering insightful analyses of their work that have contributed significantly to the field of literary criticism.

As a teacher, Harmon is beloved by his students for his enthusiasm and dedication. He has a talent for bringing poetry to life, making it accessible and engaging to even those who may have initially been intimidated by the art form. His influence extends beyond the classroom, as he has mentored and inspired countless young poets, many of whom have gone on to have successful careers of their own.

In recognition of his contributions to poetry and education, Harmon has received numerous awards and honors, including the Academy of American Poets Fellowship and the Thomas H. and Katherine B. Pike Award for Lifetime Achievement in Poetry. He was also elected a Chancellor of the Academy of American Poets in 2008, serving in the position until 2014.

Today, William Harmon continues to write and teach, sharing his unique perspective on the world through his poetry and inspiring new generations of poets and literature enthusiasts. His work stands as a testament to the power of words to illuminate and transform our understanding of the human experience.

William Reichard.response:
Viola, your eyes are the color of the sea,
the sea in a storm, the sea in any weather,
the sea in any light, the sea in any season,
the sea in any mood, the sea in any dream.
Your eyes are the color of the sea,
and your hair is the color of rain.
Your skin is the color of the moon,
and your lips are the color of a kiss.
Your voice is the sound of the wind,
and your laugh is the sound of bells.
Your heart is as deep as the ocean,
and your soul is as old as the stars.
Your beauty is timeless, eternal,
and your spirit is wild and free.
You are the daughter of the wind and the waves,
and the sister of the sun and the moon.
You are the lover of the earth and the sky,
and the mother of all that is beautiful.
You are the queen of your own domain,
and the mistress of your own destiny.
You are the light in the darkness,
and the hope in the night.
You are the song in my heart,
and the love in my life.

Born in Massachusetts in 1957, Cooper grew up with a fascination for language and storytelling. He studied English literature at Amherst College and went on to obtain a Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing from the University of Iowa.

Cooper's debut collection of poems, The Country of Here Below, was published in 1990 and received critical acclaim for its vivid depictions of rural life and landscapes. However, it was his second collection, Secret Address (1997), that brought him widespread recognition. The title poem of this collection, "Postcard from Harmony Parking Lot," captures a fleeting moment in a shopping mall parking lot, transforming the ordinary into something extraordinary through Cooper's skillful use of imagery and metaphor.

Cooper's poetry often revolves around themes of memory, place, and the passage of time, as he reflects on personal experiences and observations with a keen eye for detail. His work has appeared in numerous literary journals and anthologies, and he has received several awards and honors, including the Emily Clark Balch Prize for Poetry and the Peter I. B. Lavan Younger Poets Award.

In addition to his writing, Cooper has dedicated much of his career to teaching and mentoring aspiring writers. He has taught creative writing at various institutions, including the University of Oregon, where he was a professor for many years. He has also led workshops and served as a mentor for emerging poets, generously sharing his craft and inspiring a new generation of poets.

Cooper continues to write and publish new work, contributing to the rich tapestry of American poetry. His poems have been praised for their ability to capture the beauty and complexity of ordinary moments, offering readers a fresh perspective on the world around them. Through his writing and teaching, Cooper has left a lasting impact on the literary world, serving as a testament to the power of poetry in giving voice to our shared human experiences.
